title: WHAT I LEARNED FROM SPEAKING TO AN R.N.C. ATTENDEE FROM EVERY STATE
authors: Condé Nast, Dan Dura, Justin Bisho, Abigail Tracy, Keziah Weir, Joobin Bekhrad, Yohana Desta, Eric Lutz, Joy Press, Joanna Robinson
content:
1 / 50 Chevron Chevron Photograph by Justin Bishop . Alabama : Judy Carns “ We ’ ve been in politics for a long time and we keep sending people to Washington to make a difference and we don ’ t do that much changing . I just said , ‘ This guy ’ s got what we need . ’ ”
“ This is n't about politics , ” Ted Cruz said of his refusal to endorse Donald Trump on Thursday morning , the last day of this year ’ s Republican National Convention . He may have had something there . That ’ s what it seemed like walking the floor of the Quicken Loans Arena in Cleveland this week on assignment to meet and photograph one attendee from each of the 50 states .
At times , this year ’ s R.N.C . felt like a low-budget reality show . Because the G.O.P . has kept Trump at arm ’ s length , because of the meeting ’ s dearth of sponsors , there often weren ’ t enough bold-faced names to feed the media machine . Don King was mobbed everywhere he went . One night we saw him hiding in the seats behind the stage , taking a break to read the newspaper . They even found him there .
The people who showed up to this strangest of party meetings , were solidly un-famous and un-powerful . They seemed drawn by something more than pure political opportunity . Or maybe less ? It ’ s still less hard to say why most of them were there . Our interviews lasted no more than five minutes and it was astounding how quickly the subjects upset our expectations about them based on their appearance . Everyone was there for a different reason .
It was harder to talk to them on a personal level as the week wore on , harder to get at their natures as they started relying on the talking points we ’ d all spent hours listening to . But I ’ d say that even where we did crack the surface , with each interview we learned less and less about this complicated party .
content_original:
Trump’s America: The R.N.C. in Portrait, State by State



1 / 50 Chevron Chevron Photograph by Justin Bishop. Alabama: Judy Carns “We’ve been in politics for a long time and we keep sending people to Washington to make a difference and we don’t do that much changing. I just said, ‘This guy’s got what we need.’”

“This isn't about politics,” Ted Cruz said of his refusal to endorse Donald Trump on Thursday morning, the last day of this year’s Republican National Convention. He may have had something there. That’s what it seemed like walking the floor of the Quicken Loans Arena in Cleveland this week on assignment to meet and photograph one attendee from each of the 50 states.

At times, this year’s R.N.C. felt like a low-budget reality show. Because the G.O.P. has kept Trump at arm’s length, because of the meeting’s dearth of sponsors, there often weren’t enough bold-faced names to feed the media machine. Don King was mobbed everywhere he went. One night we saw him hiding in the seats behind the stage, taking a break to read the newspaper. They even found him there.

The people who showed up to this strangest of party meetings, were solidly un-famous and un-powerful. They seemed drawn by something more than pure political opportunity. Or maybe less? It’s still less hard to say why most of them were there. Our interviews lasted no more than five minutes and it was astounding how quickly the subjects upset our expectations about them based on their appearance. Everyone was there for a different reason.

It was harder to talk to them on a personal level as the week wore on, harder to get at their natures as they started relying on the talking points we’d all spent hours listening to. But I’d say that even where we did crack the surface, with each interview we learned less and less about this complicated party.
